study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of endovascular revascularization plus supervised exercise versus supervised exercise alone for improving walking distance and quality of life in patients with intermittent claudication.
results_summary: Combination therapy significantly improved maximum walking distance, pain-free walking distance, and quality-of-life scores compared to supervised exercise alone. No significant differences were found in general health perceptions or other SF-36 domains.
population_specificity: 212 patients with intermittent claudication in the Netherlands.
effective_dosage: Not specified (supervised exercise details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) with different electrode configurations improves coordinated force production during walking in healthy subjects and chronic stroke survivors.
results_summary: In healthy subjects, tDCS enhanced coordinated force output during walking, with dual-hemispheric stimulation showing a clearer but still small effect (4.4% increase) compared to uni-hemispheric stimulation (2.8% increase). No significant effects were observed in chronic stroke survivors.
population_specificity: Ten healthy subjects and ten chronic stroke survivors.
effective_dosage: 10 minutes of tDCS (uni-hemispheric, dual-hemispheric, or sham).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of therapeutic riding (horse therapy) on the development of children with autism, particularly focusing on gait cycle stability and mental skills.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in gait cycle stability, particularly in the sagittal plane, and suggested that therapeutic riding could be an effective additional therapy for children with autism, especially when other therapies fail. Mental skills, assessed via the PAC test, were also analyzed, though specific results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: 26 children (12 boys, 14 girls) with autism from a special needs school.

study_goal: To compare the effects of power training and high-speed yoga on physical performance in older patients with Parkinson's disease and test if these interventions attenuate symptoms and improve performance.
results_summary: Both training groups showed significant improvements in most physical measurements compared to pretests and controls, with no differences between yoga and power training. Improvements included better balance, walking speed, and strength.
population_specificity: Older patients with Parkinson's disease (mean age 72.2 ± 6.5 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess adherence to a home-based walking program in patients with an implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD) and its effects on peakVO2, while identifying reasons for nonadherence.
results_summary: Adherence to the walking program was high, with participants achieving significant improvements in peakVO2 (3.4 mL/kg/min) when adhering to at least 80% of prescribed exercise. Monitoring equipment improved adherence and safety perception.
population_specificity: 160 patients with an ICD for primary or secondary prevention (84 in the exercise arm).
effective_dosage: 60 minutes/day, 5 days/week for 8 weeks (aerobic conditioning), then 150 minutes/week (30 minutes/session) for 16 weeks (aerobic maintenance).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of pain location on outcomes after virtual walking treatment for SCI-related neuropathic pain and examine the relationship between neuronal hyperexcitability and pain reduction.
results_summary: The study found that virtual walking reduced neuropathic pain regardless of location, with a trend toward greater reduction in at-level pain. Certain sensory profiles (cold, cool, and pressure hypersensitivity) may attenuate benefits for below-level pain.
population_specificity: Individuals with spinal cord injury-related neuropathic pain (SCI-NP).

study_goal: The study does not evaluate Walking; it focuses on comparing long-term health-related quality of life and symptoms between two radiation therapies (EBRT and VBT) for endometrial cancer patients.
results_summary: The study does not address Walking; it reports higher bowel symptoms in EBRT patients compared to VBT, without significant differences in global health or functioning scales.
population_specificity: Patients with stage I high-intermediate-risk endometrial cancer.

study_goal: To evaluate the safety and tolerability of dalfampridine extended release (D-ER) in participants with chronic post-ischemic stroke deficits and assess its potential effects on sensorimotor function, particularly walking speed.
results_summary: D-ER was generally well tolerated, with adverse events consistent with previous trials. The study found a statistically significant improvement in walking speed (0.21 ft/s vs. 0.10 ft/s for placebo).
population_specificity: Participants with chronic post-ischemic stroke deficits, Fugl-Meyer Assessment lower extremity motor score ≤ 28, and ability to complete the Timed 25-Foot Walk.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if taking a long step with the nonparetic leg during walking increases muscle activation, biomechanical output, and symmetry in the paretic leg of stroke survivors.
results_summary: Participants showed increased neuromuscular activation in paretic leg muscles, particularly plantarflexors, along with improved propulsion and forward progression during the long-step adaptability task compared to steady-state walking.
population_specificity: Adults with chronic poststroke hemiparesis (N=15).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the safety, feasibility, and effectiveness of reducing sitting time (encouraging more movement, including walking) in stroke survivors.
results_summary: The protocol was safe and feasible, with no serious adverse events reported. Both intervention and control groups reduced sitting time and increased standing and stepping, but the intervention group did not show superior outcomes compared to controls.
population_specificity: Stroke survivors (N=35; mean age 66.9±12.7 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to demonstrate the safety and effectiveness of highly purified CD133+ autologous stem cells in treating critical limb ischemia (CLI), with a focus on walking recovery.
results_summary: Six out of eight patients (75%) experienced complete wound healing, rest pain cessation, and walking recovery, while two patients (25%) did not benefit and required major amputation. No complications were reported, and increased CEUS values indicated neo-angiogenesis.
population_specificity: Eight patients with stable critical limb ischemia (CLI).
effective_dosage: Not specified (CD133+ cells in buffer phosphate suspension administered intramuscularly).
study_duration: Follow-up assessments at 3, 6, and 12 months post-implant.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the feasibility and effectiveness of a short-term intervention to reduce and break up sitting-time in overweight/obese adults using prompts, goal setting, and behavioral self-monitoring.
results_summary: The intervention significantly reduced sitting-time by 1.85 hours, increased standing by 0.77 hours, and stepping by 1.09 hours, but did not increase the number of sit/stand transitions. Participants preferred longer non-sitting bouts rather than frequent interruptions.
population_specificity: Overweight/obese adults aged 37-65 years.
effective_dosage: Approximately 30-60 minutes of walking per day, with individual step goals set for transportation/home/leisure-time.

study_goal: To evaluate the effects of aerobic exercise (specifically walking) on functional capacity, disease activity, mobility, and cardiopulmonary health in patients with ankylosing spondylitis.
results_summary: Walking combined with stretching significantly improved walking distance and cardiopulmonary capacity compared to stretching alone, but did not provide additional benefits in functional capacity, mobility, disease activity, quality of life, or lipid levels.
population_specificity: Patients with ankylosing spondylitis (AS) classified by the modified New York criteria.
effective_dosage: 50 minutes of walking followed by stretching exercises, 3 times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of an educational intervention focusing on diet and physical activity (including walking) to increase physical activity levels and improve health parameters in patients with severe mental illness.
results_summary: The intervention significantly increased weekly walking METs (266.05 METs, P=0.036) but did not significantly improve BMI, waist circumference, or laboratory parameters. Total physical activity METs also increased, though not significantly (191.38 METs, P=0.086).
population_specificity: 332 outpatients with severe mental disorders (67.1% diagnosed with schizophrenia) undergoing antipsychotic treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a campus-based exercise intervention involving walking and running could reduce sedentary risk factors in university employees.
results_summary: The intervention significantly improved maximal cardiorespiratory capacity (V̇O2max), ventilatory threshold (VT), and VT velocity in both genders, with participants meeting recommended health thresholds post-intervention.
population_specificity: 56 UK university employees (age 50.7 ± 10.2 years).
effective_dosage: 25 minutes of walking/running twice per week at an intensity corresponding to individual ventilatory threshold.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the outcomes, mechanisms, and program considerations of walking-based exercise therapy for improving functional independence and quality of life in patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD).
results_summary: The study found that walking-based exercise therapy improves ambulatory outcomes and leg symptoms in PAD patients, with potential benefits from both supervised and home-based programs. The review highlights the need for detailed exercise prescriptions to quantify total exercise dose accurately.
population_specificity: Patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD) experiencing leg symptoms and ambulatory dysfunction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of robot gait training versus conventional physiotherapy in improving walking performance and functional independence in poststroke hemiparetic patients.
results_summary: The experimental group showed significant improvements in functional independence and gait speed, while the control group improved in gait endurance. Both treatments were effective, but the experimental group had advantages in daily living activities.
population_specificity: Inpatient participants with poststroke hemiparesis (<6 months after stroke), 39.3% women, average age 72±6 years.
effective_dosage: Five sessions a week for 5 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of ion channel modulation, specifically K(+) channel blockade with 4-AP (Fampridine PR), on neurological symptoms including walking speed in MS patients.
results_summary: Phase III clinical trials of Fampridine PR demonstrated improvements in neurological symptoms such as fatigue, walking speed, and strength in MS patients, though earlier trials showed mixed results.
population_specificity: Multiple sclerosis (MS) patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test whether the monoclonal antibody LY2495655 (LY) increases appendicular lean body mass (aLBM) and improves physical performance in older individuals with recent falls and low muscle strength.
results_summary: LY treatment significantly increased aLBM and showed improvements in some functional measures like stair climbing time, chair rise with arms, and fast gait speed, though no effect was detected for other performance-based measures. Injection site reactions were more common with LY but were generally mild.
population_specificity: Older individuals (aged 75+ years) with recent falls and low muscle strength and power.
effective_dosage: 315 mg LY administered subcutaneously at weeks 0, 4, 8, 12, 16, and 20.
study_duration: 20 weeks of intervention followed by 16 weeks of observation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether incorporating visuotemporal cues during walking training improves functional ability in ambulatory patients with spinal cord injury (SCI).
results_summary: Participants showed significant improvement in all functional tests after 5 days of training, with the group using visuotemporal cues demonstrating better outcomes than the control group. The findings suggest that visuotemporal cues enhance rehabilitation effectiveness for chronic SCI patients.
population_specificity: Ambulatory individuals with spinal cord injury (32 participants, chronic stage).
effective_dosage: 30 minutes/day of walking training with or without visuotemporal cues.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of a preoperative rehabilitation program, including walking, on improving clinical parameters and functional physical capacity in patients undergoing surgery for lumbar spinal stenosis.
results_summary: The study protocol was designed to evaluate improvements in walking abilities and other functional outcomes, but specific results regarding walking's effects are not provided in the abstract. The intervention group underwent a 6-week supervised program targeting strength, endurance, and cardiovascular fitness.
population_specificity: Adults over 65 with degenerative lumbar spinal stenosis scheduled for surgery.
effective_dosage: Three times per week for 6 weeks (specific walking dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of apathy in chronic neurological disorders and its differentiation from depression, with case examples involving walking-related symptoms.
results_summary: The study highlighted apathy as a significant issue in neurological disorders, distinguishing it from depression, and noted improvements in caregiver relationships and patient symptoms with appropriate interventions, though walking was not a primary focus.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic neurological disorders (progressive supranuclear palsy and mild cognitive impairment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of malnutrition on motor milestone development, including walking, in HIV-exposed children.
results_summary: Malnutrition significantly increased the odds of delayed motor milestones, including standing and walking alone, with underweight, stunting, and wasting all negatively affecting development. Low weight for age was specifically associated with delayed walking at 18 months.
population_specificity: HIV-exposed children aged 0-24 months in Malawi.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of an intervention to increase physical activity (including walking) policies and practices in childcare services and assess its impact on child physical activity levels.
results_summary: The intervention did not significantly increase overall implementation of healthy eating and physical activity policies, nor did it significantly improve child physical activity levels, including walking. However, it did increase the proportion of services with written policies and adult-guided movement activities.
population_specificity: Centre-based childcare services and attending children.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate factors influencing health-related quality of life (HRQoL) in older primary care patients and derive non-pharmacological recommendations, including the role of walking and physical activity.
results_summary: The study found that walking and increasing physical activity improved HRQoL in older patients, particularly in females and those with lower education levels, while hearing impairment and aging negatively impacted HRQoL.
population_specificity: Older primary care patients aged ≥78 years (average age 82.6 ± 3.4 years) from six cities in Germany.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how stroke lesion type, locus, extent, and prior stroke affect long-term recovery of walking ability in stroke patients.
results_summary: Gait speed improvement at 1 year was significantly reduced in participants with basal ganglia involvement and prior stroke, with a trend toward reduced improvement in those with lacunar infarctions. Right-hemisphere cortical involvement did not significantly impact outcomes.
population_specificity: 408 stroke patients from the LEAPS study database.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the drivers of patient dissatisfaction following total knee arthroplasty, particularly focusing on unmet expectations related to walking ability and other outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that patients often have overly optimistic expectations about post-surgery outcomes, including walking ability, and that unfulfilled expectations are a major source of dissatisfaction. Persistence of symptoms like pain and stiffness, as well as failure to return to preoperative function levels, are common and normal.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent total knee arthroplasty.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the medium-term functional effects of three surgical treatment modalities (microfracture, microfracture plus PRP, and mosaicplasty) for osteochondral lesions of the talus.
results_summary: All three treatments improved functional and pain scores, with mosaicplasty showing significantly better pain reduction compared to microfracture alone. The study concluded that mosaicplasty might be preferred for patients prioritizing pain control.
population_specificity: Patients with osteochondral lesions of the talus (OLT) undergoing arthroscopic surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the ecological validity of dual-task walking (DTW) paradigms as an assessment tool for executive dysfunction in neurological rehabilitation.
results_summary: The study highlights the potential of DTW paradigms to expose executive dysfunction but notes a lack of focus on ecological validity in existing research. It identifies gaps related to task, personal, and technological factors that need addressing for DTW to be fully utilized as an ecological assessment tool.
population_specificity: Individuals with acquired brain injury or degenerative neurological diseases.

study_goal: To assess the efficacy and safety of sodium channel blockers for neuroprotection in people with MS to prevent disability progression.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in disability progression, relapse rates, or MRI measurements between lamotrigine and placebo groups. Lamotrigine was associated with more rashes and transient mobility deterioration compared to placebo.
population_specificity: People with secondary progressive MS (average age ~51 years, 27.5% male).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the outcomes of open reduction alone versus combined with pelvic and/or femoral osteotomies in treating hip subluxation or dislocation in walking-age children with DDH, focusing on AVN risk, radiological and clinical results, and need for further surgery.
results_summary: Open reduction alone had a lower AVN risk (4%) compared to combined pelvic and femoral osteotomy (24%) and better radiological (97% satisfactory) and clinical results, but required more further surgeries (56%). Open reduction with pelvic osteotomy was deemed the most balanced option for durable results.
population_specificity: Children aged 12 months to 6 years with developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the relationship between aging, sarcopenia, frailty, and the diagnostic and therapeutic roles of walking capacity and muscle function.
results_summary: The study found that gait speed and hand grip strength are useful diagnostic measures for sarcopenia and frailty, and walking capacity should be part of frailty screening in geriatric assessments. Treatment overlaps for both conditions include protein and vitamin D supplementation and resistance exercise.
population_specificity: Older adults (particularly those with sarcopenia or frailty) and younger adults (<70 years) for sarcopenia screening.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of treadmill walking training with rhythmic auditory stimulation (TRAS) versus over-ground walking training with rhythmic auditory stimulation (ORAS) in improving gait abilities in chronic stroke patients.
results_summary: The TRAS group showed significant improvements in walking speed, step cycle, step length of the unaffected limb, coefficient of variation, 6MWD, and FGA compared to the ORAS group. These results suggest that treadmill walking training with rhythmic auditory stimulation may be more effective for gait rehabilitation in chronic stroke patients.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke patients (19 subjects, divided into TRAS [9] and ORAS [10] groups).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze published literature on the management of talar head fractures and propose a treatment plan based on their case.
results_summary: The study identified seven cases of talar head fractures, one of which occurred due to an inversion injury while walking. Management varied, with some cases treated surgically and others non-surgically.
population_specificity: Patients with talar head fractures (specific population not detailed beyond injury type).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study knee pain and activity levels (including walking) in patients one year after treatment for an isolated tibia fracture with an infrapatellar intramedullary nail.
results_summary: At 12 months, 11% of patients reported clinically significant knee pain, while 31%-71% had difficulty or were unable to perform routine activities like walking prolonged distances, kneeling, running, or stair climbing.
population_specificity: 437 patients with isolated tibia fractures treated with infrapatellar intramedullary nails.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of regional body composition changes (specifically reductions in visceral and intermuscular adipose tissue) in improving physical function through intentional weight loss combined with physical activity, primarily treadmill walking.
results_summary: The study found that reductions in intermuscular (IMAT) and visceral (VAT) adipose tissue were significantly associated with improved physical function (measured by SPPB scores), independent of total fat mass changes. The physical activity plus weight loss (PA+WL) group showed functional improvements, while the physical activity plus successful aging education (PA+SA) group did not, though no significant intergroup difference was detected.
population_specificity: Overweight to moderately obese (BMI 28.0-39.9 kg/m²) older adults (age 70.6±6.1 years).
effective_dosage: Not specified (treadmill walking supplemented with resistance and balance training; weight loss aimed at 7% reduction via calorie/fat restriction).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare spatiotemporal gait parameters and variability between treadmill and overground walking in healthy individuals.
results_summary: Mean gait parameters were statistically equivalent between treadmill and overground walking, but short- and long-term variability (SD1 and SD2) were significantly reduced on the treadmill, suggesting treadmill walking may induce less variable gait patterns.
population_specificity: 20 healthy participants (age 23.8±1.2 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a personalized exercise rehabilitation regimen, including walking, on vascular health, functional capacity, and quality of life in kidney transplant recipients.
results_summary: The study assessed walking as part of functional capacity measures but did not report specific results for walking alone; overall, the intervention aimed to improve multiple health outcomes in kidney transplant recipients.
population_specificity: Kidney transplant recipients (120 men and/or women).
effective_dosage: 60-minute sessions, twice a week (as part of a broader exercise regimen).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the long-term outcomes of a paclitaxel-eluting drug-coated balloon (DCB) versus conventional percutaneous transluminal angioplasty (PTA) for treating femoropopliteal lesions in patients with peripheral artery disease.
results_summary: At 24 months, DCB treatment showed significantly higher primary patency (78.9% vs. 50.1%) and lower rates of clinically driven target lesion revascularization (9.1% vs. 28.3%) compared to PTA. Both groups achieved similar functional improvements, but DCB patients required 58% fewer reinterventions.
population_specificity: 331 patients with symptomatic (Rutherford 2 to 4) femoropopliteal lesions up to 18 cm in length.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the literature to determine the gait speed attained by individuals with spinal cord injury (SCI) when using a powered exoskeleton to walk, factors influencing this speed, and study characteristics.
results_summary: The mean gait speed for non-ambulatory participants using a powered exoskeleton was 0.26 m/s, with positive correlations found between gait speed and age, injury level, and training sessions. Powered exoskeletons enabled modest walking speeds in individuals with thoracic-level motor-complete SCI.
population_specificity: Individuals with spinal cord injury (SCI), primarily non-ambulatory with thoracic-level motor-complete injuries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the benefits and harms of conservative treatments for ankle osteoarthritis (OA) in adults, focusing on non-surgical interventions like hyaluronic acid (HA) and exercise therapy.
results_summary: The study found inconclusive evidence for HA's efficacy compared to placebo or other treatments, with modest pain reduction (12% on a 100-point scale) but unclear clinical relevance. No serious adverse events were reported, but the evidence quality was low due to small sample sizes and methodological limitations.
population_specificity: Adults diagnosed with ankle osteoarthritis, primarily younger individuals with trauma-induced OA.
effective_dosage: Various HA dosages were tested, including 3 x 1 ml injections showing the best median pain reduction (30 points on a VAS scale at 27 weeks).
study_duration: Follow-up periods ranged from 6 to 12 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and effectiveness of a behavioral weight loss intervention enhanced with peer support and mHealth technology, including walking, for obese individuals with serious mental illness (SMI).
results_summary: The study found that 45% of participants lost weight and 45% improved fitness by increasing walking distance, though attendance was moderate (56% of sessions). Participants suggested modifications to enhance engagement and relevance for individuals with SMI.
population_specificity: Obese individuals with serious mental illness (SMI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the agreement between a multi-Kinect v2 set-up and a gold-standard motion-registration system for assessing gait parameters during the 10-meter walking test (10MWT).
results_summary: The study found high agreement between the multi-Kinect v2 set-up and the gold-standard system for body point time series and most gait parameters (ICC ≥ 0.888), with negligible biases and narrow limits of agreement. The multi-Kinect v2 set-up effectively matched the gold standard in providing reliable spatiotemporal gait data.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely healthy individuals or patients undergoing gait assessment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to critically review current research on the metabolic energy expenditure of ambulation in amputees, focusing on ecological validity and functional improvement.
results_summary: The study found that current metabolic testing protocols lack ecological validity as they do not replicate real-world amputee mobility conditions, raising questions about the importance of improving metabolic costs for functional mobility.
population_specificity: Amputees, particularly those with dysvascular amputation and sports/leisure participation limitations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the orthotic and therapeutic effects of daily community-applied FES on gait, spasticity, community mobility, and balance skills in children with unilateral spastic cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The FES treatment group showed significant improvements in ankle angles, stance time, step length, community mobility balance scores, and reduced gastrocnemius spasticity compared to controls, both post-treatment and at follow-up.
population_specificity: 32 children (mean age 10 yrs 3 mo) with unilateral spastic cerebral palsy and Gross Motor Function Classification System levels I or II.
effective_dosage: Four hours per day, six days per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects and cost-effectiveness of a caregiver-mediated exercise program combined with e-health services on mobility and length of stay in stroke patients.
results_summary: The study hypothesized that the CARE4STROKE program would lead to better functional outcomes and early supported discharge, potentially reducing costs, though specific results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Stroke patients admitted to a hospital stroke unit, rehabilitation center, or nursing home.
effective_dosage: 8 weeks of caregiver-mediated exercises via video-based instructions, frequency not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare energy expenditure during walking between transfemoral amputees and healthy participants on both treadmill and floor surfaces.
results_summary: Transfemoral amputees exhibited significantly higher energy expenditure (as a percentage of VO2max) compared to healthy participants, regardless of walking surface. Control participants showed minimal differences between treadmill and floor walking, while amputees had large differences.
population_specificity: Transfemoral amputees and healthy control participants.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (walking speed was self-selected as preferred walking speed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of supervised physical exercise training on exercise capacity in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in maximal and endurance exercise capacity favoring physical exercise training, with a combination of aerobic exercise and strength training being more effective than either alone in increasing 6-minute walking distance. The volume of exercise did not significantly influence training effects.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the long-term effect of PR-fampridine on patient-perceived health impact in MS patients with walking impairment.
results_summary: PR-fampridine treatment led to significant and clinically meaningful improvements in SF-36 PCS scores from baseline to weeks 12, 24, 36, and 48, with 78.5% of patients meeting criteria to continue treatment. Secondary health measures also showed significant improvements.
population_specificity: Patients with multiple sclerosis (MS) and walking impairment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the clinical features and risks of acute massive pulmonary embolism (PE) following radiofrequency catheter ablation (RFCA), particularly during the first ambulation (walking) post-procedure.
results_summary: The study found that acute massive PE, though rare (0.16% of cases), was life-threatening, with a 50% fatality rate in affected patients. Loss of consciousness during the first attempt at walking post-RFCA was a critical warning sign, and early echocardiographic detection of right ventricular dysfunction aided diagnosis.
population_specificity: Middle-aged female patients (43-52 years) who underwent RFCA for supraventricular tachycardia or idiopathic ventricular arrhythmia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 14-week functional resistance and walking program (MPACT) could attenuate declines in strength, mobility, and quality of life in head and neck cancer patients undergoing concurrent chemoradiotherapy.
results_summary: The MPACT group showed attenuated decline or improvement in strength, mobility, physical activity, diet, and QOL, with statistically significant benefits in knee strength, mental health, head and neck QOL, and barriers to exercise compared to controls.
population_specificity: Patients with head and neck cancer undergoing concurrent chemoradiotherapy.
effective_dosage: Not specified (14-week functional resistance and walking program).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility of a supervised exercise program, including walking, as an adjunctive therapy to compression for improving venous leg ulcer healing and overall health.
results_summary: The study protocol outlines a 12-week supervised exercise program combining treadmill walking, cycling, and strength exercises, but results on efficacy are pending as this is a feasibility trial. Primary outcomes focus on recruitment, retention, and adherence rates, while secondary outcomes include ulcer healing, quality of life, and physical fitness.
population_specificity: Adults receiving lower-limb compression for venous leg ulcers.
effective_dosage: Three 60-minute supervised exercise sessions per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of directional atherectomy for treating infrapopliteal artery lesions in patients with critical limb ischemia (CLI) and intermittent claudication, focusing on outcomes like primary patency and freedom from major amputation at 1 year.
results_summary: The study found that directional atherectomy achieved 84% procedure success, with 1-year primary patency rates of 89.6% for claudicants and 78% for CLI patients, and freedom from major amputation rates of 100% and 93.8%, respectively. Significant improvements in walking distance, Rutherford category, and quality of life were observed in both groups.
population_specificity: 145 patients (48.3% with CLI, 51.7% with intermittent claudication; 68.3% had diabetes) with 189 infrapopliteal lesions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the relationship between time spent out-of-home (including walking) and cognitive status, physical ability, and emotional state in older adults.
results_summary: More time spent outside the home was associated with better cognitive function, superior physical ability, and improved emotional state, as well as being influenced by weather, season, and weekday.
population_specificity: 85 independent older adults aged 65-96 years who lived alone.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of cardiac shock wave therapy (CSWT) in treating ischemic heart disease (IHD) through a meta-analysis of existing studies.
results_summary: CSWT improved angina pectoris symptoms, reduced heart failure indicators, and enhanced myocardial viability, with statistically significant improvements in various clinical measures. The therapy showed consistent benefits across multiple outcomes, though significant heterogeneity was noted among studies.
population_specificity: Patients with ischemic heart disease (IHD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the feasibility and preliminary efficacy of varied walking practice in response to visual cues for improving mobility and balance in stroke survivors.
results_summary: The study found that both treadmill and over-ground visual cue training improved walking speed, symmetry, balance, and functional mobility in stroke survivors, with no adverse events reported. Retention was a challenge, but adherence was good among participants who completed the study.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling stroke survivors with walking speed <0.8m/s, lower limb paresis, and no severe visual impairments.
effective_dosage: Twice weekly for 8 weeks (16 treatments total).
study_duration: 8 weeks (median duration varied slightly by group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how proximity and density of alcohol outlets are associated with drinking and binge drinking behaviors among college students.
results_summary: Drinkers lived closer to alcohol outlets and had significantly more outlets within a 1-mile walking radius compared to nondrinkers, but proximity and density were not associated with binge drinking frequency.
population_specificity: Full-time students at the University of Wisconsin-Madison enrolled in the Young Adults Eating and Active for Health study.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of home-based supervised exercise, hospital-based supervised exercise, and unsupervised "go home and walk advice" on walking capacity and quality of life in patients with intermittent claudication.
results_summary: Home-based supervised exercise may lead to less improvement in maximum and pain-free walking distance compared to hospital-based exercise but may improve daily life walking capacity. It may also improve walking distance compared to unsupervised advice, with little or no difference in quality of life or functional walking capacity between the approaches.
population_specificity: Patients with intermittent claudication.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of physical exercise interventions, including walking, on cognition, agitation, mood, mobility, and functional ability in individuals living with dementia in nursing homes.
results_summary: Walking interventions showed significant positive effects on cognition, agitation, mood, mobility, and functional ability in individuals with dementia in nursing homes, though the study noted heterogeneity in design and small sample sizes as limitations.
population_specificity: Individuals living with dementia in nursing homes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of running and walking on diabetes, hypertension, and cardiovascular disease risk in hypercholesterolemic patients, particularly statin users.
results_summary: The study found that running and walking significantly reduced the risk of fatal and nonfatal diabetes, hypertension, and cardiovascular disease, with greater reductions observed at higher exercise doses (MET-h/d). The benefits were substantial enough to potentially offset the increased diabetes risk associated with statin use.
population_specificity: Hypercholesterolemic patients, including statin users.
study_duration: 10.1-year mortality surveillance and 6.4-year follow-up for nonfatal events.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and efficacy of long-term whole-body vibration (WBV) training in improving mobility, specifically walking endurance, in multiple sclerosis (MS) patients.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found borderline improvement in 2-6 minute walking endurance for MS patients with low disability status, but no benefits for short-distance walking speed or balance. The methodological quality of the included studies was generally poor, and evidence for severely disabled MS patients was lacking.
population_specificity: Multiple sclerosis (MS) patients, primarily those with low disability status.

study_goal: To determine the efficacy of pentoxifylline in improving walking capacity (pain-free and total walking distance) in individuals with stable intermittent claudication, Fontaine stage II.
results_summary: Most studies suggested improvement in walking distance with pentoxifylline over placebo, but the statistical and clinical significance was unclear due to high variability and poor study quality. Pentoxifylline was generally well tolerated, with gastrointestinal symptoms being the most common side effects.
population_specificity: Individuals with intermittent claudication, Fontaine stage II.

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine whether intermittent pneumatic compression (IPC) reduces the risk of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in immobile stroke patients, not directly related to walking.
results_summary: IPC reduced the risk of DVT by 3.6% (absolute reduction) and improved survival at 6 months, but increased skin breaks. No direct findings on walking were reported.
population_specificity: Immobile stroke patients admitted to UK hospitals within 3 days of acute stroke.
effective_dosage: IPC applied for 30 days or until discharge/independent walking.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify distinct pain phenotypes of knee osteoarthritis (OA) by analyzing factors such as pathology, psychological distress, and altered pain neurophysiology.
results_summary: The study identified four distinct knee OA pain phenotypes, with varying levels of psychological distress, comorbidity, joint sensitivity, and disability. Class 4 (62% of participants) had the least pain and disability, while Class 3 (10%) had the worst disability and most pain.
population_specificity: 3,494 participants from the Osteoarthritis Initiative study (visit 6).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vitamin B12 and folic acid supplementation could slow the decline in physical performance, handgrip strength, and risk of falling in elderly individuals with elevated homocysteine levels.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in physical performance decline, handgrip strength, or fall risk between the supplement and placebo groups. However, secondary analyses suggested a positive effect on walking test scores and physical performance in compliant individuals over 80 years.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals aged ≥65 years with elevated plasma homocysteine concentrations (12-50 µmol/L).
effective_dosage: 500 µg vitamin B12, 400 µg folic acid, and 600 IU vitamin D3 daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify significant posture adaptations in older adults that help maintain gait speed despite increasing vulnerability, to guide early intervention strategies.
results_summary: Vulnerable older adults showed lower functional performance and strength but demonstrated significant posture adaptations while walking, even when maintaining good gait speed. These adaptations were more pronounced in the vulnerable group compared to healthy older adults.
population_specificity: 90 healthy community-dwelling Chinese men aged 60-80 years and 20 Chinese adults aged 21-50 years as a comparison group.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether working while walking, standing, or seated affects cognitive performance measures such as short-term memory, attention, and processing speed.
results_summary: The study found no significant changes in cognitive performance when working while seated, standing, or walking at low intensity, indicating that cognitive performance is not degraded with short-term use of alternate workstations.
population_specificity: 45 undergraduate students

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical outcomes, complications, and relapse rates of nonsurgical and surgical treatments for idiopathic congenital talipes equinovarus (clubfoot) in newborns, toddlers, and ambulating children.
results_summary: Early treatment with serial casting (Ponseti) yielded excellent or good results in most newborns, while delayed treatment in ambulating children often required surgery with mixed outcomes. Relapses were managed with re-casting or more extensive surgery, and no major complications were reported.
population_specificity: Newborns, toddlers (4-12 months), and ambulating children with idiopathic congenital talipes equinovarus (clubfoot).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (treatment involved serial casting or surgical procedures).

study_goal: The study aimed to compare the effects of mud compress therapy and hot pack therapy on cartilage destruction and subchondral bone alterations in patients with knee osteoarthritis, as measured by uCTX-II levels and other clinical outcomes.
results_summary: Both therapies reduced uCTX-II levels and improved pain and stiffness scores, with no significant difference between them. Mud compress therapy showed earlier improvement in stiffness scores compared to hot pack therapy.
population_specificity: 59 patients aged 49-74 with bilateral knee osteoarthritis.
study_duration: 2 weeks of treatment, with follow-up at 3 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of fampridine on dynamic walking characteristics and walking capacity in patients with Multiple Sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: Fampridine administration improved walking speed, endurance, and the ability to complete the 6-minute walking test, with significant increases in distance covered and faster walking/turning speeds. However, the previously observed linear decline in walking speed persisted despite treatment.
population_specificity: 35 MS patients with a median EDSS score of 4.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of Tai Chi on cardiopulmonary function and quality of life in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
results_summary: Tai Chi improved exercise capacity (6-minute walking distance) in the short, mid, and long term, as well as pulmonary function (forced expiratory volume and forced vital capacity) in the mid term. It also enhanced quality of life (dyspnoea, fatigue, and total scores) in the short term, but no significant long-term benefits were observed for pulmonary function or quality of life.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
study_duration: Varied (short, mid, and long term, but exact durations not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the relationship between intraoperative derotation osteotomies of the femur and tibia and changes in gait parameters, as well as predict postoperative outcomes based on preoperative data.
results_summary: The study found that tibial derotation osteotomies had an excellent correlation with changes in knee rotation during gait, while femoral derotation showed no significant correlation with hip rotation changes. Preoperative hip rotation during walking explained only 18% of postoperative variability.
population_specificity: 44 patients with spastic cerebral palsy, aged 6-19 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the effectiveness of behavior change techniques (goal-setting and self-monitoring) for increasing walking in older adults using N-of-1 RCTs.
results_summary: Goal-setting increased walking in 4 out of 8 individuals, while self-monitoring increased walking in 7 out of 8 individuals, with the latter's effectiveness beyond chance (p = .03). However, no intervention effect was significant for individual participants, and two participants showed a small linear decrease in walking over time.
population_specificity: Older adults aged 60-87.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the prognostic value of the 6-minute walking distance (6-MWD), transcutaneous saturation (tcSO2), and heart rate (HR) during the 6-minute walk test (6-MWT) in pediatric pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH).
results_summary: The study found that 6-MWD was an independent predictor of transplant-free survival, reflecting disease severity and exercise tolerance. Combining tcSO2-decrease with 6-MWD provided the strongest prognostic model, with larger tcSO2-decreases indicating worse outcomes.
population_specificity: Pediatric PAH patients aged ≥7 years, diagnosed and followed at a national referral center in the Netherlands.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (walking test, not a supplement).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how age and slope angles affect balance control during uphill walking by analyzing the inclination angles (IA) and the rate of change of IA (RCIA).
results_summary: The study found that elderly individuals exhibited similar IAs to younger individuals but walked slower and had reduced RCIAs. After adjusting for walking speed, the elderly showed greater IA excursions and increased RCIA during specific gait phases, indicating different balance control strategies. RCIA decreased with steeper slopes.
population_specificity: Elderly and young individuals

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a PA prescription focused solely on Walking versus one integrating PA with TV viewing on enjoyment, self-efficacy, and barriers to physical activity.
results_summary: The study found that enjoyment of PA and exercise self-efficacy significantly increased, while barriers to PA significantly decreased over the 6-month intervention for both groups, with no change in TV enjoyment.
population_specificity: Sedentary, overweight adults (n=58).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine differences in lumbar spine kinematics during walking between people with and without low back pain (LBP) and among movement-based LBP subgroups.
results_summary: People with LBP displayed significantly less overall lumbar rotation than controls, but differences in sagittal plane kinematics were not significant. Walking provoked pain in fewer than 25% of subjects with LBP, and subgroup differences in kinematics approached but did not reach statistical significance.
population_specificity: People with and without low back pain (LBP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the type and intensity of physical activity, particularly walking, reported by cardiac patients during the first year post-hospitalization and whether they met recommended PA guidelines.
results_summary: Walking was regularly performed by over 95% of cardiac patients at all three time points (6 weeks, 4 months, and 12 months post-hospitalization), highlighting its prevalence. However, moderate- and vigorous-intensity PA participation remained lower, suggesting walking may be a key behavior to modify for guideline attainment.
population_specificity: Cardiac patients (post-acute myocardial infarction, bypass surgery, or percutaneous coronary intervention) in Australia.
study_duration: 12 months (assessed at 6 weeks, 4 months, and 12 months post-hospitalization)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review evidence for spinal plasticity induced by robotic-based training in humans and propose recommendations for measuring such changes.
results_summary: The study found that robotic-assisted step training in SCI or stroke patients led to changes in spinal reflex pathways, including the re-emergence of physiological phase modulation of the soleus H-reflex during walking. Stretch reflexes elicited by joint rotations were highlighted as a potential tool for probing spinal circuitry, though current robotic devices lack integrated technology for this purpose.
population_specificity: Patients with spinal cord injury (SCI) or stroke.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a multicomponent exercise program, including walking, improves functional capacity in hospitalized elderly patients compared to conventional care.
results_summary: The study hypothesized that the multicomponent exercise program would enhance functional recovery in elderly hospitalized patients, though specific results were not detailed in the abstract. The intervention included walking as part of a broader exercise regimen.
population_specificity: Hospitalized elderly patients in a geriatrics department of a tertiary public hospital.
effective_dosage: 20-minute sessions twice daily (morning and evening) for 5-7 consecutive days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical outcomes of operative versus nonoperative treatment for displaced intra-articular calcaneal fractures (DIACFs), focusing on walking ability and other functional measures.
results_summary: Operative treatment improved walking ability and reduced shoe wear problems but increased risks of complications and infection. No significant differences were found in other functional outcomes like return to work or quality of life measures.
population_specificity: Patients with displaced intra-articular calcaneal fractures (908 participants across 7 randomized controlled trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to estimate 3D joint kinematics of lower limbs and thorax-pelvis joints during underwater walking using wearable inertial and magnetic sensors, comparing it to dry-land walking.
results_summary: Underwater walking showed a 40% lower speed, longer stride duration, and shorter stride distance compared to dry-land conditions. Joint angles in the sagittal and frontal planes differed significantly, with smoother patterns observed underwater, primarily influenced by speed and environment.
population_specificity: Eleven healthy adults.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of exercise therapy, including walking, on reducing fatigue and improving physical functioning in adults with chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS).
results_summary: Exercise therapy, including walking, was more effective than passive treatments or no treatment in reducing fatigue and improving daily physical functioning, sleep quality, and self-rated overall health. No evidence suggested that exercise therapy worsened symptoms, and serious side effects were rare.
population_specificity: Adults over 18 years with a primary diagnosis of CFS, able to attend outpatient exercise therapy.
effective_dosage: Not specified (aerobic exercise such as walking, swimming, or cycling was used).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of different surgical interventions and bone void fillers for treating tibial plateau fractures, not specifically Walking.
results_summary: The study found insufficient evidence to determine the best surgical fixation method or bone void filler for tibial plateau fractures, with mixed results favoring hybrid fixation in some outcomes but overall very low-quality evidence.
population_specificity: Adults (majority male) with tibial plateau fractures, including Schatzker types V, VI, II, and III.
study_duration: Varies by trial (e.g., 14 months in one trial, 12 months in another).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness, acceptability, and safety of treadmill training in improving gait parameters for patients with Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: Treadmill training improved gait speed and stride length but did not significantly enhance walking distance or cadence. The therapy was found to be beneficial without increasing dropout risk, though the clinical relevance of improvements was small to moderate.
population_specificity: Patients with Parkinson's disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether group-based walking could help maintain exercise capacity in persons with COPD who had recently completed pulmonary rehabilitation, compared to Tai Chi and standard care.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results for the walking intervention, as it focuses on the study design and objectives. The efficacy of walking will be assessed through secondary outcomes like physical activity engagement and exercise adherence.
population_specificity: Persons with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) who recently completed supervised pulmonary rehabilitation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the mechanisms by which supervised exercise programs improve outcomes in patients with intermittent claudication.
results_summary: Supervised exercise programs improved walking distances, endothelial and mitochondrial function, muscle strength, endurance, cardiovascular fitness, and overall quality of life in patients with intermittent claudication. The mechanisms are multifactorial and require further research for full elucidation.
population_specificity: Adults (over 18 years of age) with intermittent claudication.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of fampridine on walking, arm/hand function, fatigue, cognitive function, mood, and quality of life among responders with multiple sclerosis.
results_summary: Fampridine significantly improved walking speed (T25FW and 2MWT), arm/hand function, fatigue, mood, and quality of life in responders, with effects persisting after 28 days. No significant improvement in cognitive function was observed.
population_specificity: 30 patients with multiple sclerosis, aged 35-70, EDSS value 3.5-6.5.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of asymmetric split-belt treadmill walking on ankle and hip work during propulsion, focusing on adaptation to a novel locomotor pattern.
results_summary: The gradual training group performed significantly more work at the hip joint of the slow limb during acquisition and reduced hip joint work during retention, suggesting the hip joint on the slow limb as a site of adaptation to a new gait pattern.
population_specificity: Not specified (participants were randomized into training groups).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare a collective efficacy-enhanced walking intervention to a standard intervention for increasing physical activity and secondary outcomes in mothers.
results_summary: The study will collect quantitative data on anthropometric measurements, physical activity, and efficacy questionnaires, along with qualitative feedback from focus groups and surveys, but final results are not yet reported in the abstract.
population_specificity: Mothers with unique barriers to physical activity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of walking as part of lifestyle modifications for managing venous ulcers and chronic venous insufficiency.
results_summary: The study suggests that walking, combined with below-knee elastic stockings, is a beneficial moderate physical activity for managing venous ulcers. It helps control edema and supports overall venous health as part of a broader treatment strategy.
population_specificity: Individuals with venous ulcers and chronic venous insufficiency.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a single inertial sensor could derive frontal plane pelvic motion during gait and identify gait alterations specific to hip osteoarthritis (OA).
results_summary: The study found that hip OA patients exhibited decreased range of motion and increased asymmetry in frontal plane pelvic motion compared to knee OA patients and healthy controls. These alterations were specific to hip OA, suggesting potential diagnostic utility.
population_specificity: Patients with advanced unilateral hip OA (n = 20), advanced unilateral knee OA (n = 20), and healthy controls (n = 20).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects and biological mechanisms of a yearlong mixed exercise intervention (including walking) on side-effects, complications, and survival in patients undergoing allogeneic stem cell transplantation.
results_summary: The study did not report specific results for walking alone, but the mixed exercise intervention (endurance and resistance exercises) was designed to improve overall survival, physical performance, quality of life, and reduce complications like GvHD and infections.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing or recovering from allogeneic stem cell transplantation, excluding those with increased fracture risk, no walking capability, or severe cardiorespiratory problems.
effective_dosage: 3-5 times per week (mixed endurance and resistance exercises).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a community-based volunteer program (Baltimore Experience Corps) on increasing walking activity in older adults.
results_summary: At 24 months, women in the intervention group showed a significant increase in walking activity (1,500 more steps/day) compared to the control group, while women in the control group declined by 1,191 steps/day. No significant effect was observed in men.
population_specificity: Older adults aged ≥60 years with multiple chronic conditions living in environments that do not promote physical activity.

study_goal: To evaluate the effects of elastic band resistance training, with or without nutrient supplementation, on muscular strength and mobility-related activities in older adults living in retirement care facilities.
results_summary: Resistance training (RT) and RT with supplementation (RTS) significantly improved physical function in lower and upper extremities compared to cognitive training (CT). No additional benefits were observed from nutrient supplementation over RT alone.
population_specificity: Older adults (65-97 years, mean age 82.8) living in a retirement care facility, with no chronic diseases contraindicated for training.
effective_dosage: Resistance training performed twice weekly; nutrient supplement (rich in proteins, vitamin D, B2, B12) distributed every morning and after each RT session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vitamin D loading, ongoing supplementation, and physical exercise (including Nordic walking) could mitigate bone density and lean body mass loss after bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significantly less decline in bone mineral density, lean body mass, and bone turnover markers compared to the non-intervention group, with notable improvements in serum biomarkers. Physical exercise, including Nordic walking, contributed to these positive outcomes.
population_specificity: 220 women and similarly aged men (median age 40.7 years) with a BMI >38 kg/m² who underwent RYGB or SG procedures.
effective_dosage: 28,000 IU cholecalciferol/week for 8 weeks pre-surgery, 16,000 IU/week post-surgery, 1000 mg calciummonocitrate/day, and BMI-adjusted protein supplementation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the effects of a nurse-led walk-and-eat intervention on preserving functional walking capacity and nutritional status in patients with esophageal cancer undergoing neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy.
results_summary: The walk-and-eat intervention resulted in significantly less decline in walk distance (100-m less), hand-grip strength (3-kg less decrease), and body weight (2.7-kg less reduction) compared to usual care, along with lower rates of intravenous nutritional support and wheelchair use.
population_specificity: Patients with locally advanced esophageal cancer (stage IIB or higher), mostly male (92.9%) with squamous cell carcinoma (96.4%), mean age 59.6 years.
effective_dosage: Nurse-supervised walking three times per week and weekly nutritional advice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a self-paced walk (Exercise) with paced-breathing and a control condition on stress-related outcomes in high-stress college students.
results_summary: The self-paced walk temporarily increased energy (effect size d = 0.67) but was less effective at reducing anxiety compared to biofeedback. All conditions, including walking, significantly increased heart rate variability.
population_specificity: High-stress college students (n = 32).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of high-intensity, variable stepping training versus conventional interventions for improving walking and nonwalking outcomes in individuals 1 to 6 months poststroke.
results_summary: High-intensity, variable stepping training resulted in significantly greater improvements in walking speed, distance, temporal gait symmetry, and self-reported participation scores compared to conventional interventions, though no differences were observed in balance or sit-to-stand performance.
population_specificity: Individuals with unilateral stroke (mean duration = 101 days poststroke).
effective_dosage: ≤40, 1-hour sessions over 10 weeks (experimental group: stepping practice at 70%-80% heart rate reserve in variable contexts).

study_goal: To determine if a progressive multicomponent physical therapy intervention improves functional mobility for deconditioned older adults after acute hospitalization.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant improvements in walking speed, modified physical performance test, and Short Physical Performance Battery scores compared to the control group, with a trend toward improvement in the 6-minute walk test. No adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Homebound older adults aged 65+ (mean age 85.4) in the Denver metropolitan area.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of different ankle supports (Tubigrip(®), a stirrup brace, and a walker boot) on temporo-spatial gait characteristics in individuals without lower limb or neurological pathology.
results_summary: The study found that gait in the walker boot was significantly slower, had worse step length and single support time asymmetry, and a wider step width compared to Tubigrip(®). No important differences were observed between Tubigrip(®) and the stirrup brace.
population_specificity: 18 adult participants (average age 42, 88% female) with no previous lower limb or neurological pathology.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (intervention was ankle support use, not a dosage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the content validity, internal construct validity, reliability, and targeting of the Berg Balance Scale (BBS) for assessing postural control impairments in patients with Parkinson's disease (PD).
results_summary: The study found that the BBS lacked items critical for assessing postural responses during walking and tripping in PD patients. After modifications, the BBS-PD showed adequate internal construct validity and reliability but was poorly targeted for higher-ability patients, reducing measurement precision.
population_specificity: 285 outpatients with Parkinson's disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and safety of triple-site ventricular stimulation (TRIV) compared to conventional cardiac resynchronization therapy (CRT) and evaluate its impact on clinical outcomes.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in severe adverse events, functional improvement, or quality-of-life scores between TRIV and conventional CRT at 6 months, but TRIV showed superior benefits in ventricular remodeling at 12 months.
population_specificity: Patients with cardiac resynchronization therapy needs (76 patients across 11 centers).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify the effects of balance training (BT) on balance performance in healthy older adults and establish dose-response relationships for BT modalities.
results_summary: BT significantly improved static/dynamic steady-state, proactive, and reactive balance, as well as performance in balance test batteries. Optimal training modalities included 11-12 weeks, 3 sessions/week, 36-40 total sessions, 31-45 min/session, and 91-120 min/week.
population_specificity: Healthy community-dwelling adults aged ≥65 years.

study_goal: To compare the efficacy of intensive daily group therapy task training versus individual task training on mobility for patients with moderate to severe stroke during inpatient rehabilitation.
results_summary: No significant differences were found between group and individual therapy in mobility, gait speed, or other gait-related parameters. Both interventions were safe and equally effective.
population_specificity: Subacute stroke patients unable to walk without physical assistance.
effective_dosage: 30 sessions of 90 minutes over six weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and utility of short-acting nitroglycerin (sublingual spray and tablet) in preventing and treating acute angina attacks, particularly its impact on angina-free walking time and exercise tolerance.
results_summary: Short-acting nitroglycerin increased angina-free walking time, delayed or abolished ST segment depression, and improved exercise tolerance. The sublingual spray formulation showed clinical advantages over tablets, including faster onset and fewer headaches.
population_specificity: Patients with refractory and recurrent angina, with or without myocardial revascularization.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and validate a model combining disease activity (DAS28) and HAQ components to estimate EQ5D utilities in RA patients.
results_summary: Lower DAS28 scores and HAQ items (including walking) were associated with higher EQ5D scores, but adding DAS28 to HAQ components did not improve utility estimations. The model explained 35% of variance and had fair agreement between predicted and observed scores.
population_specificity: RA patients from the Utrecht Rheumatoid Arthritis Cohort study Group who started treatment with a biologic drug.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the literature on the course of pain and physical functioning in knee osteoarthritis (OA) patients, including prognostic factors for deterioration.
results_summary: The study found high heterogeneity in pain and physical functioning outcomes, making conclusions indistinct, but identified strong evidence for prognostic factors like baseline pain, radiographic OA worsening, and walking speed predicting deterioration.
population_specificity: Patients with knee osteoarthritis

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare kinetic outcomes (ground reaction forces, joint moments, powers, and work) between overground and self-paced treadmill walking in typically developing children and children with cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The study found significant differences in kinetic parameters between treadmill and overground walking, including lower ankle power generation, increased hip moments and work, and altered mediolateral forces due to wider step width on the treadmill. These findings suggest treadmill-specific normative data should be used for kinetic gait analysis.
population_specificity: 11 typically developing children and 9 children with spastic cerebral palsy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether interrupting prolonged sitting with short, moderate-intensity walking bouts improves glucose tolerance and metabolic function in children.
results_summary: Interrupting sitting with brief walking reduced insulin, C-peptide, and glucose levels significantly compared to continuous sitting, without affecting subsequent energy intake. The findings suggest that such interruptions can improve short-term metabolic function in children.
population_specificity: 28 normal-weight children aged 7-11 years.
effective_dosage: 3 minutes of moderate-intensity walking every 30 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the association between serum albumin (a muscle-related parameter) and muscle measures, including walking speed, in healthy young and old participants.
results_summary: The study found that serum albumin was positively associated with relative muscle mass measures in young participants but not in old participants. Walking speed was included as a muscle measure, but no specific results about its association with serum albumin were highlighted.
population_specificity: 172 healthy young participants (aged 18-30 years) and 271 old participants (aged 69-81 years) from the European MYOAGE study.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Baduanjin Qigong combined with daily walking improved gait, functional mobility, and sleep quality in Parkinson's disease patients compared to walking alone.
results_summary: The Baduanjin Qigong group showed significant improvements in sleep quality, functional mobility (Berg Balance Scale, 6-minute walk test, Timed Up & Go), and gait speed, while the control group (walking only) showed no significant changes.
population_specificity: 100 patients (ages 55-80) with mild to moderate Parkinson's disease.
effective_dosage: Daily walking for 30 minutes (both groups); Baduanjin Qigong group also performed four 45-minute sessions weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the relationship between physical activity (including walking) and outcomes in individuals with COPD, as well as the factors influencing physical inactivity in this population.
results_summary: The study found that physical inactivity in COPD patients is linked to adverse outcomes, including disease progression and increased mortality. Interventions like bronchodilators, oxygen therapy, and exercise training showed inconsistent results in increasing physical activity, likely due to complex physiological, motivational, and environmental factors.
population_specificity: Individuals with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of two trialing techniques (intermittent boluses vs. continuous infusion) for intrathecal opioid delivery in improving physical function, including walking, in patients with chronic nonmalignant pain.
results_summary: The study found significant improvement in physical function, including walking, following drug delivery system implantation, with no significant difference between the two trialing techniques. Pain reduction and functional improvements were sustained over 36 months.
population_specificity: Patients with severe intractable chronic nonmalignant pain (40 participants, 19 per cohort post-trial).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether postoperative intra-articular bolus injections of ropivacaine and ketorolac improve analgesia after total hip arthroplasty (THA).
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in morphine consumption between the treatment and control groups. Pain scores during walking were higher in the treatment group from 24-72 hours post-surgery, and readiness for hospital discharge was delayed in the treatment group.
population_specificity: 80 patients undergoing total hip arthroplasty (THA).
effective_dosage: Treatment group received 100 mg ropivacaine and 15 mg ketorolac every 6 hours for 24 hours post-surgery.

study_goal: To assess the effect of an adapted low-intensity intradialytic exercise program on muscle strength, functional capacity, and health-related quality of life in elderly hemodialysis patients (>80 years).
results_summary: The exercise group showed significant improvements in muscle strength (MQLS, HG), functional capacity (STS10, 6MWT), depressive symptoms (BDI), and health-related quality of life (EQ-5D) compared to the control group, with no adverse effects reported.
population_specificity: Elderly hemodialysis patients (>80 years) with high comorbidity and dependency.
effective_dosage: Combined exercise program using balls, weights, elastic bands, and cycle movements during the first 2 hours of HD sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of pelvic belts on sacroiliac joint (SIJ) pain, muscle activity, and gait patterns during walking in SIJ patients compared to healthy controls.
results_summary: Pelvic belts improved health-related quality of life and reduced SIJ-related pain, with decreased rectus femoris activity in patients and improved cadence and gait velocity in both patients and controls during walking.
population_specificity: 17 SIJ patients and 17 healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the efficacy of an ACT treatment program combined with SOC strategies for improving emotional well-being and functional capability, including walking ability, in elderly people with chronic pain living in nursing homes.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in pain acceptance, pain-related anxiety, compensation strategies, and pain interference in walking ability in the ACT-SOC group. No significant changes were observed in the minimal support group.
population_specificity: Elderly people (mean age 82.26, 78.6% female) with chronic pain living in nursing homes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 24-month physical activity program, including walking, improves cognitive function or reduces the risk of mild cognitive impairment (MCI) or dementia compared to a health education program in sedentary older adults.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in cognitive function or risk of MCI/dementia between the physical activity and health education groups at 24 months, except for slight improvements in executive function among participants aged 80+ or with poorer baseline physical performance.
population_specificity: Sedentary adults aged 70-89 years at risk for mobility disability but able to walk 400 meters.
effective_dosage: Structured, moderate-intensity physical activity program including walking, resistance training, and flexibility exercises (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether static foot posture assessments (using visual observation, 3-D motion analysis, and a depth camera) could predict rearfoot and midfoot kinematics during walking.
results_summary: Most static foot posture measures (85%) were not correlated with foot kinematics during walking. Visual assessment provided the best prediction model, explaining only 37% of the variance in midfoot motion, indicating weak predictive ability.
population_specificity: 31 males with an average age of 22.5 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine gender-related differences in outcomes following supervised exercise therapy (SET) for intermittent claudication (IC), focusing on walking distance, quality of life, and walking ability.
results_summary: Women with IC showed significantly lower improvements in absolute claudication distance (ACD) during the first 3 months of SET and had shorter walking distances after 12 months compared to men, though both sexes improved. No differences in quality of life were observed, but women reported less improvement in some walking ability subdomains.
population_specificity: Patients with intermittent claudication (113 men and 56 women).
effective_dosage: Three 30-minute sessions per week initially, adapted based on individual needs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether higher intensity treadmill training (HI-TM) produces greater improvements in VO2 peak compared to lower intensity treadmill training (LO-TM) in stroke survivors.
results_summary: HI-TM participants showed significantly greater gains in VO2 peak (+34%) than LO-TM participants (+5%), but there were no significant differences in 6MWD, 30WT, or 48SC between the groups.
population_specificity: Stroke survivors with disabling stroke.
effective_dosage: HI-TM at 80% heart rate reserve (HRR), LO-TM at 50% HRR.

study_goal: To assess the effectiveness, acceptability, and safety of treadmill training in improving gait parameters for patients with Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: Treadmill training improved gait speed and stride length but did not significantly improve walking distance or cadence. The therapy showed no increased risk of patients dropping out, and adverse events were not reported.
population_specificity: Patients with Parkinson's disease

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the relationship between mobility, balance, and frailty, and how walking assessments can differentiate healthier and frail adults for potential interventions.
results_summary: The study found that walking speed and dual/multi-task conditions effectively differentiate healthier and frail adults, suggesting potential for screening and pre-emptive interventions.
