Mobility and balance interventions were noted to reduce falls risk, though dementia patients walked too fast for their frailty level, complicating rehabilitation ethics.
population_specificity: Older adults, particularly those with frailty or dementia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of lithium carbonate on ataxic features in patients with spinocerebellar ataxia type 3/Machado Joseph disease (SCA3/MJD) and to assess the metric properties of ataxia scales for future studies.
results_summary: Lithium showed efficacy on cerebellar NESSCA scores and SCAFI in patients able to perform the 8-meter walking-time test, but no effect was observed on non-ataxia features. The study suggested that ataxia scales should be preferred as primary outcomes in future trials.
population_specificity: 62 patients with SCA3/MJD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether short-duration, high-dose n-3 PUFA supplementation improves endothelial function and inflammation in patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD).
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in endothelial function between the fish oil and placebo groups, but fish oil supplementation significantly reduced triglycerides and increased omega-3 index and pro-resolving mediators.
population_specificity: Patients with stable claudication due to peripheral artery disease (PAD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a weight loss intervention involving physical exercise on the energy cost and stride frequency during walking in obese teenagers.
results_summary: The exercise intervention significantly increased walking speed, reduced body mass and fat percentage, and decreased energy cost of walking at various stride frequencies, with greater reductions at higher frequencies. No significant changes were observed in the control group.
population_specificity: Obese teenagers aged 13-16 years.
effective_dosage: Three 60-minute weekly sessions of high-intensity intermittent activities coupled with aerobic training.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of the Stride Management Assist (SMA®) System and functional task-specific training (FTST) on spatiotemporal gait parameters in stroke survivors.
results_summary: Both SMA and FTST interventions significantly improved gait parameters, including velocity, cadence, swing time, double support time, stride length, and step length. The SMA group showed additional improvements in step length on the impaired side and reduced spatial asymmetry during fast walking.
population_specificity: Stroke survivors with gait impairments (n=50).
effective_dosage: Training 3 times per week for 6-8 weeks, up to 18 sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the feasibility and efficacy of high-speed gait training using an exoskeleton robot (HAL) compared to conventional physical therapy in improving gait and balance in chronic stroke patients.
results_summary: The HAL group showed significant improvements in walking speed (55.9% increase), reduced steps (17.6% decrease), and increased cadence (32.8% increase), along with better performance in balance tests, while the control group showed no significant changes.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke patients (n=18, split into HAL and control groups).
effective_dosage: 20 minutes per session, once a week for 8 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility, safety, and perceived patient response to a combined tDCS and exercise intervention for knee osteoarthritis, and to gather data for a future fully-powered trial.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of the intervention, as it describes a pilot study designed to assess feasibility and safety rather than efficacy outcomes.
population_specificity: 20 individuals with knee osteoarthritis reporting a pain score of 40 or more on a 100 mm visual analogue scale during walking.
effective_dosage: 20 minutes of tDCS (active or sham) immediately prior to 30 minutes of supervised muscle strengthening exercise, twice weekly for 8 weeks, plus unsupervised home exercises twice weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of accumulated standing, cycling, and walking on ambulatory blood pressure (ABP) versus a sitting-only day in overweight or obese adults.
results_summary: Walking (1.0 mph) reduced systolic blood pressure (SBP) compared to sitting, with a 4% reduction in SBP load. However, cycling showed greater reductions in SBP and diastolic blood pressure (DBP) than walking.
population_specificity: Overweight or obese adults (BMI 28.7 ± 2.7 kg/m², age 30 ± 15 years).
effective_dosage: Accumulated 2.5 hours of walking (1.0 mph) during an 8-hour simulated workday.
study_duration: Each condition (including walking) was performed 1 week apart.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of strength, power, coordination, and multimodal exercise training on habitual and fast gait speed in healthy older adults.
results_summary: The study found that resistance, coordination, and multimodal training similarly improved gait speed by approximately 8.4%, with large effect sizes (0.84 overall). These interventions helped slow or delay age-related gait speed loss.
population_specificity: Healthy older adults (age ≥65 years, mean age 74.2 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of an auditory hallucinatory symptom management program versus routine care (including walking) on symptoms in patients with chronic schizophrenia.
results_summary: The control group, which included walking as part of routine care, showed no significant improvement in anxiety symptoms, and the study did not highlight specific benefits or drawbacks of walking itself. Walking was part of the control group's routine care but was not the primary focus of the study.
population_specificity: 58 patients with chronic schizophrenia experiencing auditory hallucinations, from psychiatric inpatient rehabilitation wards in northern Taiwan.
effective_dosage: 20 minutes of walking as part of routine care.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the role of physical activity, including walking, in managing frailty and preventing its progression to disability.
results_summary: The study suggests that physical activity, including walking, is a key intervention for frailty, helping to correct deficits and ameliorate symptoms. It highlights the importance of multi-domain assessments and targeted interventions to improve outcomes in frail older adults.
population_specificity: Older adults at higher risk for adverse health outcomes, such as those with frailty characterized by weight loss, muscle weakness, low physical activity, and slow walking speed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether allopurinol could prolong the time to leg pain and improve walking capacity in patients with peripheral arterial disease (PAD).
results_summary: The study found no significant improvement in pain-free or maximum walking distance, exercise capacity, blood vessel function, or self-assessed health and walking ability after allopurinol treatment. Uric acid levels significantly decreased, but this did not translate to functional benefits.
population_specificity: Patients with peripheral arterial disease (PAD), mean age 68.4 ± 1.2 years, 78% male.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare gait improvements (using the Gait Deviation Index) between two types of total hip arthroplasty (THA) and identify predictors of postoperative gait improvement.
results_summary: Patients who received large-head THA showed less improvement in gait (GDI) compared to those who received 28/32 mm THA. Preoperative GDI score was the only predictor of postoperative improvement, while factors like WOMAC, age, gender, and walking speed were not significant.
population_specificity: 35 patients undergoing THA, with 20 age-matched adults providing normative gait data.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (surgical intervention, not a supplement).
study_duration: Gait analysis was conducted before surgery, and at 2 and 6 months post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of pulmonary hypertension (PH)-specific therapy in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
results_summary: The study found that PH-specific medications improved hemodynamic parameters (e.g., reduced pulmonary vascular resistance and mean pulmonary arterial pressure) but did not significantly improve dyspnea, walking distance, or other clinical markers.
population_specificity: Patients with severe PH (mPAP ≥35 mm Hg) and COPD.
effective_dosage: Not specified (various PH medications used, including endothelin receptor antagonists, phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors, and combination therapies).

study_goal: The study aimed to compare the effectiveness and postoperative recovery outcomes of laparoscopic appendectomy (LA) versus open appendectomy (OA) in adults with complicated appendicitis.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in postoperative complications, including surgical site infections, between LA and OA groups. The only notable difference was in the time to walking, which was not further detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Adults diagnosed with complicated appendicitis (peritonitis or abscess formation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of brisk walking with stretching exercises versus yoga on arterial function, blood pressure, and cardiac autonomic activity in elderly individuals with increased pulse pressure.
results_summary: The study found that brisk walking did not produce significant changes in arterial stiffness, blood pressure, or autonomic function, while yoga showed significant improvements in these measures. The results suggest yoga was more effective than brisk walking for the studied outcomes.
population_specificity: Elderly subjects with pulse pressure ≥60 mmHg (n=30 in the brisk-walking group).
effective_dosage: 1 hour of brisk walking with stretching exercises, 6 days per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the characteristics and potential advantages of physiotherapeutic interventions, including walking, in subjects on awake ECMO support.
results_summary: The study found that subjects on awake ECMO usually received a combination of passive and active physiotherapy, with most achieving an acceptable degree of autonomy after treatment. Preliminary evidence supports the safety of early mobilization and ambulation in these patients.
population_specificity: Patients on awake veno-venous ECMO support with potentially reversible respiratory/cardiac failure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a single session of cerebellar anodal transcranial direct current stimulation could improve symptoms in patients with ataxia.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in ataxia symptoms, including better scores on the Scale for the Assessment and Rating of Ataxia, the International Cooperative Ataxia Rating Scale, the 9-Hole Peg Test, and the 8-Meter Walking Time, compared to sham stimulation.
population_specificity: Nineteen patients with ataxia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate gait symmetry in poliomyelitis subjects using a powered knee-ankle-foot orthosis compared to a conventional drop-locked orthosis.
results_summary: The powered orthosis improved gait symmetry in step width, swing time, stance phase percentage, and knee flexion during swing phase, but showed no significant differences in step length, stance time, double-limb support time, or walking speed.
population_specificity: Seven subjects with poliomyelitis who routinely wore conventional knee-ankle-foot orthoses.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the sustainability of TENS effects on reducing ankle plantar-flexor spasticity and improving gait speed in post-stroke patients.
results_summary: TENS (both 30 and 60 minutes) reduced ankle plantar-flexor spasticity and improved walking ability, with longer durations showing greater spasticity reduction. No significant difference was found in timed up and go test scores between groups.
population_specificity: Post-stroke patients (30 participants, mean age 46.46 years).
effective_dosage: TENS for 30 or 60 minutes plus task-oriented exercises, five sessions per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a multinutrient supplement containing DHA and other components could improve mobility and cognition in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The study found that the supplement improved habitual walking speed and cognitive performance in two tests, with higher blood DHA levels compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women aged 60-84 years.
effective_dosage: 1g DHA, 160 mg eicosapentaenoic acid, 240 mg Ginkgo biloba, 60 mg phosphatidylserine, 20mg d-α tocopherol, 1mg folic acid, and 20 µg vitamin B12 per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the therapeutic effect of an 8-week walking/running aerobic exercise program on depressive symptoms in patients with unipolar depression.
results_summary: The study found a large and clinically significant reduction in depressive symptoms (HRSD-17 scores), but only moderate, non-significant changes in BDI-II scores and small, non-significant changes in physical fitness measures.
population_specificity: 46 outpatients aged 18-65 with mild to severe depression (ICD-10 criteria).
effective_dosage: Not specified (participants attended 58% of exercise sessions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the criterion and construct validity of three walking tests (6MWT, ISWT, ESWT) compared to CPET, as well as their clinical applicability in individuals with NSCLC.
results_summary: The ISWT showed moderate criterion validity with CPET peak oxygen consumption, while the 6MWT and ESWT had poor relationships. The 6MWT demonstrated moderate construct validity with respiratory function, but no walking tests correlated with function, strength, or HRQoL. The ESWT had a ceiling effect, and all walking tests were safe and required minimal time and personnel.
population_specificity: Individuals with stage I-IIIb NSCLC (n=20, 40% male, mean age 66.1 ± 6.5 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Bobath-based individually designed trunk exercises improve trunk control, balance, and walking ability in stroke patients compared to conventional exercises.
results_summary: The study found that both groups improved in some measures, but only the study group showed significant gains in balance (BBT, FR) and walking (10m test). No significant differences were observed between groups post-treatment.
population_specificity: Stroke patients (mean age ~55 years, stroke duration ~58-67 months).
effective_dosage: 1 hour per session, 3 days a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the clinical and psychometric properties of observational gait assessment scales in people with neurological disorders.
results_summary: The G.A.I.T. scale was found to be the most suitable for clinical practice and research due to its validity, reliability, and sensitivity to change. Other scales like the TGS and RVGA showed varying degrees of effectiveness depending on the neurological disorder.
population_specificity: People with neurological disorders, including multiple sclerosis, Parkinson disease, normal pressure hydrocephalus, and Huntington disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a two-month walking program on implicit postural control strategies in patients with major depressive disorder (MDD).
results_summary: MDD patients showed improved postural performance, particularly in challenging conditions (e.g., foam surface), suggesting enhanced ability to make efficient postural corrections. The walking program positively impacted center of pressure (COP) velocity-based variables, indicating benefits for daily activities and autonomy.
population_specificity: Adults with major depressive disorder (MDD) and age- and BMI-matched healthy controls (HC).
effective_dosage: One-hour supervised walking sessions, three times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of different endurance exercise models (including walking-based activities) in increasing physical fitness in individuals with intellectual disability (ID) and obesity.
results_summary: The study found that type II endurance exercise (lower extremity muscles endurance exercises for 10 RM followed by cardiorespiratory endurance exercises for 26-27 minutes) was more effective for increasing lower extremity muscle endurance, while type I (similar but with 20 RM and 24-25 minutes) was more effective for improving cardiorespiratory endurance in ID patients with obesity.
population_specificity: ID patients with obesity aged 10-30 years old from Special Schools in DKI Jakarta.
effective_dosage: Type I: 20 RM lower extremity exercises + 24-25 minutes cardiorespiratory exercise; Type II: 10 RM lower extremity exercises + 26-27 minutes cardiorespiratory exercise; Type III (control): threw a tennis ball for 10 minutes. All interventions were performed 3 times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effect of an intradialysis NMES training program on muscular strength, functional capacity, and quality of life in haemodialysis patients.
results_summary: The NMES group showed significant improvements in quadriceps strength, sit-to-stand performance, walking distance (6MWT), and quality of life (EQ-5D), but reported more symptoms like muscular pain and cramps compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Haemodialysis patients (mean age 69.7 years, 54% men, average 32.1 months on HD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the reliability of the visual (VIS) method for detecting muscle activation onset during walking with three automated algorithms (STH, AGL-step, KM) across different gait speeds.
results_summary: The AGL-step algorithm showed the best agreement with the VIS method (RMSE 0.86-6.95% of GC), followed by STH and KM. Intra-rater reliability for VIS varied by muscle (12.51-45.08% of GC), and a single rater had large errors (RMSE 8-23% of GC).
population_specificity: 10 healthy young adults (4 male, 6 female; mean age 28.5±4.2).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the 12-month primary patency of directional atherectomy in diabetic versus nondiabetic claudicants with peripheral artery disease.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in 12-month primary patency between diabetic (77.0%) and nondiabetic (77.9%) claudicants, with both groups showing improved secondary clinical outcomes like Rutherford category, ankle-brachial index, and walking impairment. Directional atherectomy was effective for both populations without stents.
population_specificity: Claudicant patients (Rutherford category 1-3) with peripheral artery disease, including diabetics (46.8%) and nondiabetics.

study_goal: To compare the efficacy of a 3-month non-surgical treatment program (MEDIC-treatment) versus usual care in reducing pain-related measures and sensitization in knee osteoarthritis patients not eligible for total knee replacement.
results_summary: The MEDIC-treatment group showed greater improvements in peak pain intensity and pain after 30 minutes of walking compared to usual care, but both groups experienced reduced sensitization. The findings suggest non-surgical treatment is more effective for pain reduction, while sensitization improvements were similar between groups.
population_specificity: Patients with knee osteoarthritis not eligible for total knee replacement.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the validity and reliability of neurodevelopmental endpoints, including walking milestones, in infant formula supplementation trials with DHA and ARA.
results_summary: The study found that recording time to milestones like walking was used as an endpoint in one short-term study, but none of the endpoints, including walking, demonstrated long-term predictive properties for neurocognitive assessment. No beneficial effects of DHA/ARA supplementation on neurodevelopment were observed in long-term follow-up studies.
population_specificity: Neonates and infants participating in DHA/ARA supplementation trials.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and durability of drug-based endovascular treatments (DCB and DES) for femoropopliteal interventions in improving walking capacity and reducing restenosis.
results_summary: The study found that drug-coated balloons (DCB) and drug-eluting stents (DES) showed superior mid-term and long-term outcomes compared to traditional treatments, with significant improvements in walking capacity and reduced need for target lesion revascularization. DCB demonstrated effectiveness even in complex lesions, while DES showed excellent clinical outcomes up to 5 years.
population_specificity: Patients with femoropopliteal lesions, including TASC II A and B lesions, long lesions, and in-stent restenosis.
study_duration: Follow-up data up to 5 years for DES

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the repeatability and variability of plantar pressure patterns, including mean, peak, and asymmetries, during walking in elderly individuals.
results_summary: The study found that mean and peak plantar pressure values were consistent across different days, but asymmetry indexes suggested repetitive asymmetric loading during locomotion in the elderly, which may warrant further investigation for potential articular injuries.
population_specificity: Ten elderly subjects (5 female), mean age 73±6 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a structured walking intervention could improve quality of life, psychosocial functioning, and psychiatric symptoms in chronic schizophrenia patients.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in quality of life (SF-36), psychiatric symptoms (PANSS), and personal and social performance (PSP) in the walking intervention group compared to the treatment-as-usual group. The intervention group showed notable reductions in positive and negative symptoms and general psychopathology, along with enhanced physical and social functioning.
population_specificity: Chronic schizophrenia patients (n=104) in a psychiatric institution.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a robotic-based gait rehabilitation strategy (Loko-R) could feasibly and effectively improve skilled walking in individuals with motor-incomplete spinal cord injury (m-iSCI).
results_summary: Loko-R training was feasible and showed better performance in skilled overground walking tasks (SCI-FAP) compared to conventional training, with sustained improvements at follow-up assessments. Participants in Loko-R reported higher perceived exertion but no severe adverse effects.
population_specificity: Individuals with chronic (>1 year) motor-incomplete spinal cord injury (m-iSCI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a powered exoskeleton for overground ambulation in nonambulatory persons with paraplegia, focusing on oxygen uptake and heart rate during sitting, standing, and walking.
results_summary: The study found that walking with the powered exoskeleton significantly increased oxygen uptake and heart rate compared to sitting or standing, indicating improved physical activity and potential fitness benefits for persons with paraplegia.
population_specificity: Eight nonambulatory persons with paraplegia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of low-dose exercise training (walking) on peak VO2/kg, haemodynamics, and other clinically relevant parameters in patients with pulmonary hypertension and right heart failure.
results_summary: The study found that low-dose exercise training significantly improved peak VO2/kg, cardiac index at rest and during exercise, mean pulmonary arterial pressure, pulmonary vascular resistance, 6-minute walking distance, quality of life, and exercise capacity in PH patients. The training group showed a 24.3% improvement in peak VO2/kg compared to minimal change in the control group.
population_specificity: Patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension and inoperable chronic thrombo-embolic PH (54% female, 56 ± 15 years, 84% WHO functional class III/IV, 53% on combination therapy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a designed walking program for people with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) could facilitate regular physical activity without increasing pain levels.
results_summary: The walking program was feasible, acceptable, and safe, with no reported adverse effects or increased pain. The intervention group showed improvements in self-efficacy and global well-being, though no statistically significant between-group differences were observed.
population_specificity: Thirty-three people with rheumatoid arthritis recruited from rheumatology outpatient clinics.
effective_dosage: Walking route with three loops, completed 3-4 times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of virtual reality training with cognitive load (VRTCL) on walking function in chronic stroke patients.
results_summary: Both VRTCL and control groups showed significant improvement in walking function under single and dual task conditions after 4 weeks. The VRTCL group demonstrated greater improvement in the dual task condition compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke patients (mean age ~59 years, post-stroke duration ~269 days).
effective_dosage: 30 minutes per day, five times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize evidence on the benefits of exercise training, including walking, for improving functional, symptomatic, and quality-of-life outcomes in individuals with multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: The study found that exercise training, including walking, yields small but important improvements in walking, balance, cognition, fatigue, depression, and quality of life in MS patients. The paper highlights the need for further research and promotes exercise as part of clinical care for MS.
population_specificity: Individuals with multiple sclerosis (MS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of conventional, multisensory, and dual-task exercises on balance ability in older community dwellers.
results_summary: All three training groups showed significant improvement in balance (FAB scores), with no statistically significant differences between groups. No significant changes were observed in gait stability ratio or walking speed.
population_specificity: Older community-dwelling adults (n=44).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the influence of aerobic exercise (walking) and yoga on fatigue, pain, and psychosocial status in patients with multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: Walking, as part of the aerobic exercise program, improved fatigue, physical function, emotional and social roles, energy, mental status, and overall hygiene while reducing pain and fatigue in MS patients. No significant differences were found between yoga and aerobic exercise groups post-intervention.
population_specificity: 90 patients with multiple sclerosis (MS).
effective_dosage: 25-30 minutes of walking per session, three sessions per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate 5-year changes in gait biomechanics, radiographic outcomes, and patient-reported outcomes after unilateral concomitant medial opening wedge HTO and ACL reconstruction in patients with varus malalignment and ACL deficiency.
results_summary: The study found a substantial decrease in the knee adduction moment in the surgical limb and slight increases in the nonsurgical limb, along with decreases in knee flexion moments in both limbs. Secondary outcomes showed sustained improvements at 5 years, though some declines were observed in both limbs from 2 to 5 years.
population_specificity: 33 patients (mean age 40 ± 9 years) with varus malalignment, medial compartment knee OA, and ACL deficiency.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility of a study protocol comparing whole-body vibration (WBV) to standard exercises (EXE) in people with Multiple Sclerosis (PwMS) and to determine if WBV is more effective for improving outcomes like walking endurance.
results_summary: The study found WBV feasible with high compliance and low drop-out rates. Standard exercises showed large effect sizes for vibration threshold improvements, but no significant differences were found between groups for muscle strength, balance, or gait.
population_specificity: People with Multiple Sclerosis (PwMS) with minimal gait impairments (mean age 48.1 ± 11.2 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify variables associated with work-related difficulties or unemployment in persons with multiple sclerosis (MS), including the impact of walking problems.
results_summary: The study found strong evidence that walking problems, along with other factors like expanded disability status scale, MS duration, age, and fatigue, significantly impact work-related difficulties in MS patients. Rehabilitation interventions were noted as effective for mobility and walking difficulties, but their impact on vocational outcomes was not addressed.
population_specificity: Persons with multiple sclerosis (75% females, total sample of 31,192 patients).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and timing (early vs. standard) of two rehabilitation techniques (PNF and CTE) for functional recovery after acute ischemic stroke, particularly focusing on motor outcomes like walking.
results_summary: Early rehabilitation showed significant improvements in the Barthel Index at 12 months and better performance in the Six-Minute Walking Test and Motricity Index compared to delayed rehabilitation, regardless of the technique used. The study found no difference in disability outcomes at 3 months but highlighted a time-dependent effect on motor recovery, especially in lower limbs.
population_specificity: 340 patients with first-ever sub-cortical ischemic stroke in the MCA territory and contralateral hemiplegia, admitted within 6-24 hours of symptom onset.
study_duration: Intervention outcomes were measured at 3 and 12 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate gait parameters in healthy elderly subjects to understand age-related changes in walking patterns.
results_summary: Older adults exhibited shorter steps, slower walking, increased step width, and prolonged double support, likely as compensatory strategies for stability and energy efficiency. They also showed reduced gait symmetry and higher metabolic energy consumption compared to younger subjects.
population_specificity: Healthy elderly subjects

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding a concurrent cognitive task differentially affects walking in persons with transfemoral amputation using microprocessor knees compared to controls.
results_summary: The study found no significant differential effect of a cognitive task on walking between the groups, but people with transfemoral amputation walked slower, with wider steps and more asymmetry compared to controls under both conditions. The conservative walking strategy adopted by amputees may reduce the need to concentrate on walking but contributes to gait deviations.
population_specificity: Persons with transfemoral amputation using microprocessor knees and age- and sex-matched controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how medial and lateral zoned textured insoles affect postural stability during walking under normal and impaired visual conditions.
results_summary: Impaired vision increased foot CoP variability while walking. Laterally zoned insoles significantly increased the rate of medial-lateral CoP change, suggesting potential postural instability.
population_specificity: 15 asymptomatic subjects

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether weight-bearing biofeedback training could improve weight-bearing symmetry and functional joint moments in patients after unilateral total knee arthroplasty during walking and sit-to-stand tasks.
results_summary: The study found no improvement in weight-bearing symmetry, but biofeedback training increased knee extension moments during walking and improved sit-to-stand test times compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent unilateral total knee arthroplasty.
effective_dosage: Not specified (standard-of-care rehabilitation augmented with biofeedback training).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of wearing a thoracolumbosacral orthosis with an advanced reciprocating gait orthosis on energy expenditure and gait parameters in spinal cord injury patients.
results_summary: Walking speed, distance walked, and physiological cost index improved when patients used the thoracolumbosacral orthosis alongside the advanced reciprocating gait orthosis compared to using the gait orthosis alone. The trunk extension provided by the thoracolumbosacral orthosis likely contributed to these improvements.
population_specificity: Four patients with spinal cord injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify habitual walking speed in nursing home residents and identify potential predictors of walking speed, including demographic, health, and functional outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that 97% and 75% of participants had walking speeds below 0.8 m/s and 0.5 m/s, respectively. Physical activity status before age 50 and daily sitting time were identified as independent predictors of walking speed, though the regression model only explained 25% of the variance.
population_specificity: Nursing home residents (N=102, randomly selected from 11 nursing homes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of supervised pain-free treadmill exercise on improving walking performance in women with intermittent claudication due to peripheral arterial disease compared to men.
results_summary: Female participants showed significant improvements in walking distance (752%), duration (278%), and rate (115%), while men improved by 334%, 149%, and 80%, respectively. The study found no significant differences between groups, suggesting women benefit similarly from the low-intensity treadmill program.
population_specificity: Women and men with peripheral arterial disease and symptoms of intermittent claudication (n=26, women=9, mean age=67.58±5.59 years).
effective_dosage: 45-minute treadmill walk, twice per week, below the participant's minimal pain threshold.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if inflammation during treated HIV-1 infection worsens physical impairment, including walking performance, in older individuals.
results_summary: The study found no evidence of inflammation-associated physical impairment in HIV-infected individuals compared to uninfected controls, despite elevated inflammatory biomarkers. Walking performance (400 m walking speed) and other physical measures were similar between groups.
population_specificity: Older HIV-infected individuals (54-69 years) on suppressive antiretroviral therapy and uninfected controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of functional impairments, including difficulties with walking, on incident clinical fractures in older women with diabetes mellitus.
results_summary: The study found that older women with diabetes mellitus had a greater risk of clinical fractures, and functional limitations in moderate physical activities like walking several blocks partially mediated this risk.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling women aged 65 and older (EPESE cohort) and postmenopausal women (WHI cohort).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of suprascapular nerve block plus physical therapy (PT) versus PT alone for treating adhesive capsulitis of the shoulder, not specifically evaluating Walking.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in walking ability between the two groups, as it was not applicable (P = not applicable). Other pain and functional parameters improved significantly in both groups, with some additional benefits favoring the injection group.
population_specificity: 41 patients with adhesive capsulitis of the shoulder.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare sex differences in walking recovery, return to community living, and mortality 30 and 60 days after hip fracture surgery.
results_summary: Men had higher 60-day mortality but similar walking recovery and likelihood of returning home compared to women. No differences were found in walking ability among nursing home residents.
population_specificity: Individuals with hip fracture (N = 2,016; 24% male).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether torsion adapters in prostheses reduce shear stress and improve motion during unplanned turns in trans-tibial amputees.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant reduction in peak transverse plane moments with torsion adapters, but transverse plane rotation was observed in all participants, suggesting potential benefits for reducing shear stress and improving comfort in individual cases.
population_specificity: 10 trans-tibial amputees

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of non-sedation versus sedation with a daily wake-up trial on physical function, including walking distance, in critically ill patients after discharge from the intensive care unit.
results_summary: The study did not report specific results regarding walking, as it is a planned investigation within a substudy of 200 patients, focusing on 6-minute walking distance among other physical function outcomes.
population_specificity: Critically ill, intubated, mechanically ventilated patients with expected duration of mechanical ventilation >24 hours, excluding those with severe head trauma, coma, or other specific conditions.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (intervention involves sedation protocols, not a dosage of walking).
study_duration: Duration of mechanical ventilation (not explicitly stated, but expected >24 hours).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the function of the advanced reciprocating gait orthosis (ARGO) with dorsiflexion-assist ankle-foot orthoses on walking parameters in able-bodied individuals and those with spinal cord injury.
results_summary: Walking with ARGO significantly reduced walking speed, step length, and cadence in able-bodied individuals and altered hip, knee, and ankle joint range of motion in both groups. Spinal cord injury subjects showed greater differences in walking parameters compared to able-bodied subjects when using ARGO.
population_specificity: Six able-bodied individuals and four spinal cord injury subjects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a biomimetic bi-cruciate retaining (BCR) knee implant could restore more natural kinematics during walking and other activities compared to contemporary implants.
results_summary: The biomimetic BCR implant demonstrated kinematics similar to healthy knees during walking, deep knee bend, and chair-sit, outperforming contemporary ACL-preserving and ACL-sacrificing implants. The study suggests that restoring native knee geometry with ACL preservation improves kinematic performance.
population_specificity: Not specified (implied patients requiring knee implants, but no demographic details provided).

study_goal: To compare the effectiveness of different posterior decompression techniques versus conventional laminectomy for treating degenerative lumbar stenosis.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in functional disability, leg pain, complications, or postoperative walking distance between the techniques. Perceived recovery was slightly better with bilateral laminotomy, and some techniques showed fewer cases of iatrogenic instability and less postoperative back pain, though the differences were small.
population_specificity: Patients with degenerative lumbar stenosis (733 participants across 10 RCTs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of standard shoes versus rocker shoes on functional mobility and energy expenditure in post-stroke hemiplegic patients using ankle-foot orthosis.
results_summary: Rocker shoes significantly improved functional mobility (reduced timed up and go time, increased preferred walking speed) and decreased oxygen cost compared to standard shoes. No significant changes were observed in the standard shoes group.
population_specificity: Post-stroke hemiplegic patients using ankle-foot orthosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare factors contributing to performance on single- and dual-task Timed "Up & Go" (TUG) tests in older adults.
results_summary: The study found that age, hip extensor strength, walking speed, general mental function, and Stroop scores were significantly associated with performance on all TUG tests. Different independent factors influenced single-task (mental function) and dual-task (age for manual, focused attention for cognitive) TUG performances.
population_specificity: Adults over 50 years old living in the community.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a new corrective method (FAS+OS) for reducing forefoot adduction in children with moderate congenital talipes equinovarus (CTEV) during walking age.
results_summary: The FAS+OS group showed significant improvements in bimalleolar angle and bean-shape ratio compared to other methods (DB and DB+OS), suggesting better correction of forefoot adduction and improved plantar pressure distribution.
population_specificity: Children with moderate CTEV deformities (n=53, aged walking age).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of additional medications (bronchodilators with or without inhaled corticosteroids) on physical activity (PA) in COPD patients and identify factors predicting PA improvement.
results_summary: Medication improved PA, particularly at higher intensities (≥3.0 METs and ≥3.5 METs), with the improvement correlated with baseline lung volume but not with pulmonary function or exercise capacity changes.
population_specificity: 21 COPD patients without other conditions reducing physical activity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a Kinect-based exergame could improve muscle strength, balance, and walking in healthy elderly individuals.
results_summary: The study found that the exergame significantly improved walking, muscle strength, and motor function in the intervention group, with notable improvements in balance (BBS, FRT) and chair-stand performance (CS-30) compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Healthy elderly individuals (n=57, aged not specified).
effective_dosage: Once or twice a week, up to 24 total sessions.
study_duration: Duration not explicitly stated, but up to 24 sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the clinical interest of ambulatory assessment of physical activity and walking capacity in patients with lower extremity peripheral artery disease (PAD).
results_summary: The review identified 96 studies, with 87 focusing on ambulatory-measured physical activity or energy expenditure in PAD patients, highlighting its use in assessing activity patterns, characterizing walking patterns, and controlling training load. The remaining studies assessed walking capacity, emphasizing community-based evaluation, new outcome measures, and patient self-perception.
population_specificity: Patients with lower extremity peripheral artery disease (PAD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess lower body pain and physical function in older adults with previous femoral neck fractures, comparing outcomes based on the type of surgery received.
results_summary: Hip fracture patients reported more pain than the reference group, with internal fixation patients experiencing the most pain and walking difficulties. No significant differences in performance-based physical function were found among fracture groups, but the reference group outperformed all fracture groups.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults aged 60+ with previous femoral neck fractures (n=115) and reference subjects without lower limb injuries (n=31).
study_duration: Follow-up ranged from 1.6 months to 7.5 years post-fracture.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether using cement in hemiarthroplasty for displaced femoral neck fractures in elderly patients improved pain and activity scores compared to cementless procedures.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in hospital stay, complications, or mortality between cemented and cementless groups. However, the cemented group showed better walking ability and pain scores in the early follow-up period.
population_specificity: Elderly patients (mean age 78.16 years, range 60-110) with displaced femoral neck fractures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy, engagement, and feasibility of an online social networking physical activity intervention with pedometers delivered via Facebook app for increasing walking and moderate-to-vigorous physical activity.
results_summary: The intervention significantly increased weekly moderate-to-vigorous physical activity (MVPA) by 135 minutes and walking time by 155 minutes at 8 weeks, but these effects were not sustained at 20 weeks. No significant changes were observed in vigorous activity or quality of life measures.
population_specificity: 110 adults (mean age 35.6 years) recruited online in teams of 3-8 friends.
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention included self-monitoring, social elements, and pedometers).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the associations between multiple comorbidities, including walking, in COPD patients compared to non-COPD controls.
results_summary: The study identified walking as one of the clinical variables analyzed in the network-based associations of comorbidities in COPD patients, but no specific effects or outcomes related to walking were detailed.
population_specificity: 1969 COPD patients and 316 non-COPD controls

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of automated mechanical peripheral stimulation (AMPS) on gait and clinical status in Parkinson's disease (PD) patients.
results_summary: AMPS treatment improved walking velocity, step and stride length, and walking stability in PD patients, with benefits lasting up to 10 days post-treatment. The improvements were consistent with clinical scale measurements, suggesting a more stable walking pattern and reduced fall risk.
population_specificity: 18 PD patients and 15 age-matched healthy controls.
effective_dosage: Six AMPS sessions, once every 4 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of anti-dementia drugs on gait performance (specifically stride time parameters) in patients with Alzheimer's disease, considering drug type and walking conditions.
results_summary: Anti-dementia drugs significantly improved gait performance, with memantine reducing stride time variability under single-task conditions and acetylcholinesterase inhibitors (AChEIs) improving stride time under dual-task conditions. No significant change was observed in the mean stride time.
population_specificity: Patients with Alzheimer's disease

study_goal: To determine if walking rehabilitation improves functioning and quality of life in 65- to 85-year-old persons who had a stroke within the previous 3-36 months.
results_summary: Walking distance and both self-reported and measured functioning improved significantly during rehabilitation, though quality of life and balance measures remained unchanged. The intervention showed statistically significant improvements in motor skills, self-care, and functional independence.
population_specificity: 65- to 85-year-old persons who had a stroke within the previous 3-36 months.
effective_dosage: Inpatient (20 days) or outpatient (18 days) rehabilitation, followed by 10-15 individual physiotherapy sessions and home exercises.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of physical rehabilitation therapies, including walking, on improving activities of daily living for people with critical illness myopathy (CIM) and polyneuropathy (CIP).
results_summary: The study found no published RCTs or quasi-RCTs that examined whether physical rehabilitation interventions, including walking, improved activities of daily living for people with CIP and CIM. No data were suitable for meta-analysis.
population_specificity: People with acquired weakness syndrome due to CIP/CIM.
